article.title: UVI colour gradients of 0.4<z<1.4 star-forming main sequence galaxies in CANDELS: dust extinction and star formation profiles

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure illustrate about the relationship between galaxy size and stellar mass?
choices: There is no correlation between galaxy size and stellar mass.
Galaxy size increases linearly with stellar mass.
Galaxy size decreases with stellar mass.
Galaxy size generally increases with stellar mass, but with significant scatter.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which statement accurately describes the comparison between UVJ and UVI diagrams for classifying galaxies?
choices: The UVI diagram cannot differentiate between star-forming and quenched galaxies.
The UVJ diagram is useless for high-redshift galaxies (z > 0.4).
Both diagrams effectively separate quiescent galaxies from star-forming ones and show similar patterns for sSFR and AV.
Only the UVJ diagram can accurately estimate sSFR and AV.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the parallel trajectories of color gradients with the Calzetti reddening vector in this figure suggest?
choices: Stellar population variations are the main cause of color gradients.
Dust extinction is more significant than stellar population changes in driving color gradients.
sSFR increases significantly with radius.
Galaxy centers are quenched at a resolution of 0.18 arcseconds.

multiple_choice_question.text: What significant trend regarding dust extinction (AV) is revealed in this figure?
choices: AV profiles show a steep drop from center to edge, similar to stellar mass density.
AV values are highest in low-mass galaxies.
AV profiles are independent of redshift.
The ratio of AV to stellar mass surface density increases significantly outward, indicating high dust content in outer regions despite low stellar mass.
Dust extinction at 2800 ˚A.
Specific star formation rate (sSFR).
Stellar mass.
Star formation rate (SFR) based on the dust-corrected luminosity at 2800 ˚A.
